item.title: Chile’s Leftist Presidential Hopefuls Spar Over SQM-Codelco Deal
item.description: Chile’s left-leaning presidential contenders clashed over a landmark deal signed last year between lithium supplier SQM and state-owned Codelco, highlighting differences ahead of the sector’s primary vote.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Malinowski

media:content.media:description: Jeannette Jara speaks to members of the media after registering her candidacy in Santiago on April 30.

item.title: Israel Holds Rates as Inflation Spikes, Gaza War Escalates
item.description: Israel’s central bank kept interest rates on hold for the 11th time in a row, maintaining a wait-and-see stance amid increased military operations in Gaza and an uptick in inflation.
item.dc:creator: Galit Altstein

item.title: Lagarde Sees Opportunities to Raise Euro’s Global Profile
item.description: President Donald Trump’s erratic policies offer a “prime opportunity” to strengthen the euro’s international role and allow the currency bloc to enjoy more of the privileges so far reserved for the US, European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde said.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Weber, Mark Schroers, Jana Randow

media:content.media:description: Christine Lagarde at the Hertie School in Berlin. Photographer: Krisztian Bocsi/Bloomberg

item.title: Shipping Bottlenecks in Europe Send a Warning to US, Asia
item.description: Port congestion is worsening at key gateways in northern Europe and other hubs, according to a new report which suggests trade wars could spread maritime disruptions to Asia and the US and push up shipping rates.
item.dc:creator: Brendan Murray

media:content.media:description: The container terminal at Bremerhaven port in Bremerhaven, Germany, on April 22, 2025.

item.title: Chinese, EU Trade Heads to Meet as Trump Tariff Tensions Rise
item.description: Top trade officials from the European Union and China are planning to meet again early next month, another sign that both sides are stepping up engagements as they try to push back against tariff pressure from Donald Trump.
item.dc:creator: Colum Murphy, Jorge Valero

media:content.media:description: He Lifeng with Maros Sefcovic on March 27, in Beijing.

item.title: Moody’s Rethinks Its Rating Spectrum on the G-7
item.description: I’m Craig Stirling, a senior editor in Frankfurt. Today we’re looking the shift in view by Moody’s on Italy. Send us feedback and tips to ecodaily@bloomberg.net. And if you aren’t yet signed up to receive this newsletter, you can do so here.
item.dc:creator: Craig Stirling

item.title: Swiss Desire for a Trump Trade Deal Tests Its Love for Farmers
item.description: The UK may have been first to clinch some sort of trade accord with the US, but Switzerland has reason to hope it’s not far behind. Earlier this month, Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said both countries were “at the front of the queue” for a deal.
item.dc:creator: Craig Stirling, Bastian Benrath-Wright

item.title: Trump Extends Deadline for 50% Tariffs on EU Goods to July 9
item.description: President Donald Trump said he would extend the deadline for the European Union to face 50% tariffs until July 9 after a phone call with Commission President Ursula von der Leyen.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer A Dlouhy

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump walks to speak to members of the media before boarding Air Force One at Morristown Municipal Airport in Morristown, New Jersey, May 25, 2025.

item.title: Romania Boosts Liquidity to Calm Markets After Rates Spike
item.description: Romania’s central bank injected the highest amount of liquidity to the domestic market in almost seven years as it sought to bring down short-term interest rates that spiked because of recent political turmoil.
item.dc:creator: Andra Timu

media:content.media:description: The headquarters of Romania's central bank in Bucharest. Photographer: Andrei Pungovschi/Bloomberg

item.title: Hungary Warns Wage-Hike Plan at Risk From Weak Economy
item.description: Hungary’s government warned it may need to renegotiate minimum wage hikes planned for 2026 due to weaker-than-expected growth, in the latest downbeat economic outlook from officials.
item.dc:creator: Marton Kasnyik

media:content.media:description: A market vendor in Budapest. Photographer: Akos Stiller/Bloomberg

item.title: ECB Faces Greater Risk Inflation Will Undershoot 2%, Simkus Says
item.description: There’s a growing danger that inflation will fall short of the European Central Bank’s 2% target, according to Governing Council member Gediminas Simkus.
item.dc:creator: Milda Seputyte

media:content.media:description: The ECB headquarters in Frankfurt, Germany. Photographer: Alex Kraus/Bloomberg

item.title: Japan’s Stocks Solid as Trump Rhetoric Cools; Nippon Steel Gains
item.description: Japanese shares gained for a second day on hopes of softer trade policies from US President Donald Trump, after he extended the deadline for higher duties on European Union goods and backed a deal between Nippon Steel Corp. and US Steel Corp.
item.dc:creator: Alice French, Toshiro Hasegawa

item.title: African Central Banks to Join EM Peers Easing Rates
item.description: Central banks in key African economies are getting set to line up with other emerging-markets in coming weeks and cut interest rates where inflation pressures are seen abating, or stay on guard where the path is less clear.
item.dc:creator: Monique Vanek

item.title: Japan to Sell Rice Stockpiles With Aim to Halve Soaring Prices
item.description: Japan will sell additional stockpiles of rice at a fixed price with an aim to halve soaring costs, newly-appointed agriculture minister Shinjiro Koizumi said as the country heads toward a summer election.
item.dc:creator: Sakura Murakami

media:content.media:description: A bag of packaged rice. Photographer: Kiyoshi Ota/Bloomberg

item.title: Israel Set to Hold Rates as Inflation Spikes, Gaza War Escalates
item.description: Israel’s central bank is set to keep interest rates on hold for the 11th time in a row, amid increased military operations in Gaza and an uptick in inflation.
item.dc:creator: Galit Altstein

item.title: Japan Touts Ships Expertise, LNG Project as Tariff Talks Key
item.description: Japan may offer financial and technical contributions ranging from investment in an Alaskan LNG pipeline project to shipbuilding expertise as it seeks to smooth the path toward a tariff deal with the US by mid-June.
item.dc:creator: Yoshiaki Nohara

item.title: Asean Must Keep Joining Global Supply Chains, Thailand Says
item.description: Southeast Asian nations should look at ways to further integrate their supply chains regionally and around the world to reap the benefits of economies of scale and gain access to larger markets, Thailand’s foreign minister said.
item.dc:creator: Patpicha Tanakasempipat

item.title: Kashkari Says ‘Not Sure’ on Interest Rate Moves by September
item.description: Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis President Neel Kashkari said major shifts in US trade and immigration policy are creating uncertainty for Fed officials to move on interest rates before September, as the Trump administration continues tariff talks with numerous governments.
item.dc:creator: Katia Dmitrieva, Haslinda Amin

item.title: Malaysia’s Anwar Writes Trump Seeking Summit With Southeast Asia
item.description: Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim said he personally wrote to Donald Trump seeking to organize a meeting with Southeast Asian nations amid concerns over the US president’s proposed tariff hikes.
item.dc:creator: Philip Heijmans

item.title: Rayner Leaves Door Open on Benefit Reform as Farage Ups Pressure
item.description: UK Deputy Prime Minister Angela Rayner left the door open on whether the government will lift the two-child benefit cap even as Nigel Farage’s Reform UK seeks to outflank the ruling Labour Party in bringing down the cost of living.
item.dc:creator: Kit Rees

media:content.media:description: Britain's Deputy Prime Minister and Levelling Up, Housing and Communities Secretary Angela Rayner arrives at 10 Downing Street ahead of the meeting between Cyprus' President Nikos Christodoulides and Britain's Prime Minister Keir Starmer, in central London, on May 21, 2025. (Photo by JUSTIN TALLIS / AFP) (Photo by JUSTIN TALLIS/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Fed to Take in Stride Another Month of Tame Inflation
item.description: The Federal Reserve may take comfort that tariffs have yet to materially boost official inflation readings, but policymakers will continue to suggest interest rates are on hold until they better understand the coming impact of US trade policy.
item.dc:creator: Vince Golle, Craig Stirling

media:content.media:description: Pedestrians near the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, US, on Wednesday, April 9, 2025. Stocks soared after President Donald Trump said he’d pause some tariffs on dozens of countries for 90 days, signaling a tentative reprieve in trade hostilities that has wiped out trillions from global markets and ignited fears of a US recession.
